review:
They took away Overwatch 1, as well as a sizeable chunk of Overwatch 1s content and replaced it with a free to play game filled to the brim with manipulative tactics. 

The gameplay is good, but cannot be separated from how insidious charging for new , unbalanced heroes is. 

I have 700+ hours in Overwatch, 300 or so of it in 2, but I just can't recommend trying to get into this as a new player.

There's such a massive grind- or paywall, to catch up to people in playable heroes.
The devs respect their players as much as they respect the women in their office.
the only thing that's good about this game is porn

cat

Once upon a time, I had a cat, I had ten dollars, I would buy it food for eight dollars, bathe it often, and it was very sticky to me.

Later, I took it out to play, passers-by thought it was cute, they fed it cat food, ham sausage, I was very unhappy because it was mine. I wanted to carry it home, but he broke away from me and meowed at the person who gave it good food, I hugged him a few times and he didn't go with me, and scratched me, so I turned around and left.....

Later, I came across it by chance on the road, and it was dirty. Passers-by will only give it good food and play with it, but they will not take it home and bathe it. It saw me and followed me home, I shut it out, it meowed outside the door, it was very uncomfortable,
[b]but I wouldn't want it anymore.[/b]

15 pavos por 3 misiones de historia? a chuparla

Yes, OW2 does actually deserve the almost 90% negative reviews it's getting. This isn't just the internet getting it's panties in a wad or blowing something out of proportion.

This game is pretty much everything wrong with gaming in 2023.
I had 125 hours on this game, never playing it again. Fuck Blizzard, just doing my part to get this game to Overwhelmingly Negative.

This is going to sound like hyperbole but this game single handedly saved the FPS genre on PC, specifically multiplayer FPS. 

Typically, most multiplayer FPS games tend to lose their population quickly. CoD franchise always burned me on this. Unless it was Counter-Strike, TF2 or (sometimes) Battlefield, good luck finding a game a month or later after launch, especially when you play late night/early morning US like me. I'm not entirely sure that's changed much, though.

I followed OW from the day it was announced. I listened to them talk about it, fell in love with their passion as they talked about the 'ballet of violence' between Tracer and Widowmaker or how Quake III and Unreal Tournament influenced them or how they looked to all those classic FPS games for inspiration for both heroes and how the game should play. 

Even when the rest of the Blizzard dev teams sounded like they'd lost their passion, OW didn't.

The game launched, it was everything I'd hoped for, gameplay wise.

Movement felt great, guns felt great, heroes synergized well. That Quake and UT DNA is there and present.

Through all the game's ups and downs, that part never changed. It was always fun to play, except for when it gets frustrating.

And it can get frustrating. Being matched with people well beyond your skill level. A player base that at times seems to despise the game and everything about it and yet perplexedly keeps playing. Switching to 5v5 which I go back and forth on in how I feel, and the disappointment over their lack of candor on PVE.

And an annoying focus on competitive e-sports over the amazing promise of the world setting, characters and lore. It was those things, this promise of hope in the face of adversity, of heroes and villains larger than life, this message of positivity in a sea of dark and gritty stories. That's why I fell in love with this universe. That's why I've written tens of thousands of words of fanfic. I even got interviewed about the fandom and being involved in it.

So it's always been a disappointment that they've failed to really capture that.

But over the past year I feel like they've been doing a lot more to build on the lore, they've done a great job of keeping the game fresh, and some of that promise and potential might finally be realized.

I feel like this game is an 8/10 that could be an 11 if they just let themselves play in the sandbox they've made.

2k hours in game and for the most part it is a fantastic game with top tier gameplay, characters, and lore. That being said, the microtransactions that were introduced with Overwatch 2 have completely ruined the fun for me. Blizzard you need to cut your prices in half at the bare minimum. $20+ for a skin for a single character in an FPS is pure insanity to me, not to mention heroes being locked in the battlepass which is a big No No. Gameplay is good but anticonsumer practices bring the game down for me. Can't recommend.
